titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: A copy of the Treaty for the annexation of Texas with all the correspondence communicated with it, printed in confidential secresy for the use of the Senate, by some treachery was conveyed to the table of the Editor of the New-York Evening Post—and they have been all published— Letters from Henry Clay, Martin van Buren and Thomas H. Benton, all concurring in the injustice and impolicy of annexing Texas at this time to the United States have been published within the last five days, and the reading them has consumed so much time, that my diary runs again into arrears, and my head into confusion.— This was the day of the first whig convention at Baltimore to nominate Henry Clay as their candidate for the Office of President of the United States for four years from the fourth of March next, and to agree upon a Candidate for the Office of Vice President— They met accordingly 275 in number from the 26. States, equal to the Constitutional number of the two houses of Congress; and what never has happened in either house of Congress, the whole number from every State was present— Ambrose Spencer of New-York was President, and Henry Clay of Kentucky was unanimously nominated as their Candidate for President. At the fourth time of voting viva voce they fixed upon Theodore Frelinghuysen of New-Jersey as their Candidate for the Vice Presidency— Mr Connell called here this evening and gave us this information received from Baltimore by the Telegraph— I stop’d at Haas’s shop this morning at the request by Letter of Mr Lambden, to have a full length Daguerrotype likeness of me taken, to assist Mr Lambden to finish his Portrait of me— Haas was not ready for me this day, and I promised to call again to-morrow— At the house there was a motion pending to cease debate on the tariff bill and take it out of the Committee of the whole on Wednesday the 8th.— Dromgoole moved as an amendment to substitute Monday the 6th. lost by yeas and nays 23 to 101. The resolution was then adopted without a division.— This and the two following days had been assigned for the District business— But Campbell chairman of the District Committee is absent from indisposition and by general consent the first three Legislative days after closing the debate on the tariff were substituted instead of the present days. The tariff bill was further debated in Committee of the whole by Bidlack, Buffington, Hubard, Grinnell, Dunlap and Pollock till past 4— Cobb of Georgia took the floor—the Committee rose and the house adjourned— I gave the last sitting for my portrait to Gibert.

I was up once or twice in the course of the Night— There was much commotion in the city of delegates to the ratification Convention this day at Baltimore. I finally rose at four, and soon after five, my son departed to meet Josiah Quincy junr in the Thomas viaduct 9 miles short of Baltimore, to proceed thence on a Western tour to Cincinnati, Louisville, St. Louis Detroit and by lake Erie to Buffalo and western New-York. My son has been with us only four days, and I feel as if it were a final parting— Yet I cherish the hope that we shall meet again within two months at Quincy.— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer and gave to Mr Gales a copy of Mrs Addicks’s newly published French grammar, and requested him in her behalf, to notice it on the Newspaper, which he promised to do. About a month has passed since I received from Mrs Addicks, a letter, with two copies of her book one as a present to me, and requesting me to deliver the other to the Editors of the Intelligencer, and she desired my opinion upon her book, and a puff from the Intelligencer— I neglected to answer her Letter, till yesterday there came a second Letter of more than female resentment, and reproach— It spurred me on to deliver the copy to the Editors of the Intelligencer— I stop’d next at Haas’s office, and he took one Daguerrotype likeness of me, for Mr Lambden but the day was dark and beclouded and the light was not propitious, and I promised if it should be better to morrow morning to call again— At the house there was a bare quorum to do business, without failure— Duncan moved a reconsideration of the vote assigning the first three legislative days after closing the debate on the tariff bill, to the business of the District of Columbia— But the debate on the question of reconsideration was postponed— The bill from the Senate for reducing the rates of Postage, limiting and regulating the franking privilege, and for preventing frauds on the Post office was referred to the Committee on Post-Offices and Post roads— The Committees were called for reports— Then, Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hopkins in the chair on the tariff bill— Hour speeches from Howell Cobb of Georgia, Joseph M’Dowell of Ohio, Joseph R Ingersoll, and David L. Seymour of New-York—two and two. Absalom H. Chappell of Georgia took the floor for to morrow the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Edward Cruft here this morning and the Revd. Aaron Foster in the Evening.

The heat of dog days has again prematurely returned upon us. Mr Joseph Day, and Mr Abner P. Nash are two of the Massachusetts Delegates to the Baltimore Clay Convention of the young men, who ratified yesterday the nomination made by the elders the day before of Henry Clay of Kentucky to be President, and Theodore Frelinghuysen of New Jersey to be Vice President of the United States, for four years from the 4th. of March next. The nominating convention consisted of 275 members, each State having a number equal to that of her representation in the two houses of Congress The nomination was unanimous, adopted by exclamation and with shouts of unbounded enthusiasm— Yesterday the convention numbered thousands—perhaps tens of thousands, and the ratification was as unanimous and enthusiastic as the nomination. All this day a succession of the delegates from sundry States, visiting Washington before their return home were introduced to me in the house, and about 20 of them called on me at my house in the Evening— On my way to the house I stop’d again at Haas’s shop, and he took three more Daguerrotype likenesses of me, one of which is for Mr Lambden at Philadelphia— At the house after sundry preliminaries, they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hopkins in the Chair on the Tariff bill— Absalom H. Chappell of Georgia, and who in Georgia passes for a whig, made an hour speech in favour of the bill—followed by Luther Severance of Maine in a speech of equal longitude on the other side of the question.— Henry C— Murphy of Brooklyn Long Island descanted against the tariff— Julius Rockwell of the 7th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, pronounced his maiden speech, an impressive one, not quite animated enough, for the tariff. The new member from the Pittsburgh— Pennsylvania District, quite a young man supported the same cause with more ardour and vehemence— Andrew Kennedy took the floor, but the Committee rose— Cave Johnson moved a suspension of the rules, for a resolution to grant the use of the hall, for the friends of peace to-morrow evening—only 52 voted for it.— The Speaker, concluded that it was useless to put the negative of the question— The Resolution was lost— Adjourned—

The stream of visitors, returning delegates from the Baltimore conventions is yet copious and unabated. many of my old acquaintances come to shake hands with me as they pass, and many others ask to be introduced to me for the same purpose. Their names are seldom pronounced by their introducers so that I distinctly hear them, and their names and their persons slip alike from my memory, the moment they part from me. But they consume time, and multiply subjects of excitement tending to distraction— At the same time the Treaty for the annexation of Texas to the United States, with the President’s message transmitting it to the Senate and the accompanying documents, prematurely published, and the conflicting opinions of the leading men of the Union, disclosed in Letters and speeches at public meetings, all indicate the immediate crisis of a great struggle between Slavery and Freedom throughout the world— I must retire from this contest, or perish under it probably before the close of the present year, or even of the present Session of Congress— The issue is precipitated by its bearing on the approaching Presidential election. It is John Tyler’s last card for a popular whirlwind to carry him through, and he has played it with equal intrepidity and address. He has compelled Clay and Van Buren to stake their last chance upon opposition to the measure now, and has forced himself upon the whole democracy as their exclusive candidate for the Presidency next December.— I called this morning at the Bank of the Metropolis, and deposited there my Son’s draught on the Merchants Bank at Boston for 254.87. for the balance due from him to Mr Thomas B. Johnson at the time of his decease.— On reaching the house, I found them in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Hopkins in the chair upon the tariff bill, and Andrew Kennedy the prime bawler of the democracy, howling and bullying at the tariff of duties levied on the planter and farmer to put into the pocket of the manufacturer, and raving at the abominable doctrine of protection Charles Hudson followed with a cool solid and judicious argument for the principle and a mass of statistical details in support of it— The slack tide of debate then came— No one started for the floor. David L. Seymour called for the question on his amendment, 30 instead of 15 percent ad valorem on coarse wool, per pound— Collamer moved an amendment to the amendment. 3 cents per pound additional, and strike out the rest of the section— Collamer began to speak but Duncan disputed his right and claimed the floor to discuss the bill. Hopkins decided that Collamer had the right to the floor, but he gave it up and withdrew his amendment— Duncan was not ready and moved the Committee to rise. Adjourned after 2. Evening Music in the Presidents grounds.

I attended public worship alone this morning at the Hall of the house of Representatives, where I found a stranger, making a prayer, with Mr Tuston the Chaplain to the Senate, at the Clerk’s Table— The hall was crowded and I had some difficulty, in obtaining a seat— The preacher from the Speaker’s chair, was the Revd. William Dwight of Portland Maine a son of the celebrated Dr Dwight—some time President of Yale College. His text was from Hebrews 11.27—“for he endured, as seeing him who is invisible”— The first part of the verse is—[“]By faith he (Moses) for sook Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king.”—was not part of the text but after some slight reference of the application of the text to Moses the main discourse was a delineation of the character of the man who endures as seeing him who is invisible— It was deeply impressively eloquent and solemn. After the close of the service, Mr Tuston introduced Mr Dwight to me— I walked home, accompanied by Mr Stout from western New-York, whom I saw last October at Canandaigua one of the most noted of the delegates from New York to the late Baltimore nominating convention— He was going to dine with his representative Charles Carroll at his brother’s— After dinner at the second presbyterian church, I heard again Mr Dwight, from Matthew 11.28. “Come unto me all ye, that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest—” A sermon more affecting and solemn than that of the morning— The division was first into the invitation—the classes of mankind, to whom the invitation was addressed, and the promise to those who will come, and secondly, the several classes of the labouring and heavy-laden to whom the invitation was addressed—the heavy laden with cares—with sorrows—with sin—each of these furnished varieties of specification deeply pathetic—cares for personal wants—for support of families; for the well being, health, conduct and good name of children— Sorrows—all the ills that flesh is heir to— Disease of body and of mind—reverses of fortune— Loss of children and of friends. Sins—the grievous burden of a wounded conscience— Loss of reputation—open transgression, and the reproach of the world— Come unto me says the blessed Jesus, to all these sufferers, and I will give you rest.— How tender—how affectionate! how altogether lovely!— And will you not accept this invitation?— This was the final appeal—urged with prevailing power. To me it was emphatic warning—would that its effects could have been permanent upon my Soul.— The heart was edified by the exhortations of these discourses—but the conduct remains unchanged— David Lee Child was here this evening. He goes for New-York to-morrow.

Last Saturday the report signed— John C. Calhoun Secretary of State was received by the house, upon the Resolution adopted at my motion on the 26th. of February last, enquiring whether any gross errors have been discovered in the census, as corrected at the Department of State in 1841—. . .— The report, is at once insulting to the house, evasive of the enquiry and false by equivocation— The journal of the house this morning referring to the report declared that it stated that no gross errors had been discovered— I moved to strike out those words from the journal, for the report does not deny the existence of the errors but taking advantage of a blunder in the copy of the Resolution sent to the Department substituting 1843 for 1841. to evade a direct answer to the Resolution affecting to deny the existence of a census corrected in 1843. and that after the correction of 1841 there has been no re-examination of the census and no material errors discovered— My motion started a debate very soon arrested by a motion from Weller for the previous question; and with great difficulties obtained the yeas and nays which were 32 and 126— I then moved a suspension of the rules to refer to a select committee the report from the Secretary of State, with instructions to enquire into the fact of the errors of the Census, and report thereon to the house— The Speaker said there was already a motion to suspend the rules, which was made by M’Kay to go into the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Tariff Bill— But Romulus M. Saunders, claimed a privileged right to report in part from the select Committee on the fray between John White and George Rathbun. He said that it would occasion no debate, but he counted without his host. As to the quarrel between White and Rathbun they reported only the testimony of 34 witnesses— No resolution.— As to the case of William S. Moore, who fired the pistol, and wounded Wirt the policeman The committee had no doubt of the power of the house to punish him for the contempt, but they thought it most expedient to turn him over to the judicial tribunals, and reported a resolution to that effect, which was adopted. As to the third charge upon the Committee to report a Bill or Resolution for punishing or repressing disorders in the house for the future, they were not ready to report as yet—and he moved to lay the report and testimony on the table and print; and he moved the previous question— The report was however not satisfactory to Mr White moved to recommit the report, which raised a rancorous debate of four hours, after which the debate was postboned to next Thursday week, and the report and testimony to be printed— Then at 4 Committee of the whole Union, Hopkins in the chair, and Duncan made a half of an hour speech and moved the Committee to rise and the house adjourned— Evening visitors as reported in the margin—

General Erastus Root a long celebrated and popular politician of the State of New-York and of the Delegates to the Clay-Convention of the last week at Baltimore, called on me this morning to solicit my interposition with the Mexican President Santa Anna to obtain the release of Cyrus K Gleason, one of the Texan Prisoners taken at Mier, and confined in the Castle at Perote— He went from the neighbourhood of General Root’s residence—and he read to me a memorial numerously signed by his neighbours intreating his good offices to liberate the young man, and particularly to apply for mine— Mr Henry Johnson a Senator from Louisiana came to my seat yesterday with a Letter from J. H. Leverich dated New-Orleans 20. April last, requesting him to procure my good offices in the same way for a young man named Hedenberg (A. D) of a respectable family in New-Jersey, in the same predicament with Gleason— I answered in both cases that if the relations of Peace with Mexico should be restored I would apply to General Almonte so far as may be proper, believing that the present existing state of things forbids any application from me to the Mexican President— Mrs Telfair was also here this morning— The Committee have reported a bill for her relief, and she came to urge me to call it up. I had expected that the Death of Henry R. Brinkerhoff a member from Ohio who had never taken his seat, and the notice of whose decease was received here yesterday would have been received announced this morning, with the usual obituary notices, and an adjournment of the house without doing any business—instead of which I found Dr Duncan, delivering in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, first Weller and then Hopkins in the chair, the second half of his anti-tariff speech which he had broke off in the middle, yesterday.— Hardin of Illinois followed him for an hour on the Tariff side, and then Robert Barnwell Rhett of South-Carolina vapoured away his hour, upon the inconsistency of a tariff for protection with the natural rights of mankind— This Prince of Slavemongers is eternally raving against the injustice of taxing one man for the benefit of another.— The next blatant orator against the tariff was George A. Caldwell of Columbia 4th. Congressional district of Kentucky.— Alexander H. Stevens of Georgia, swept away all this dust as a gale sweeps the Pennsylvania avenue. George Rathbun came next—chilling cold after Stevens’s furnace—while he was prosing Winthrop came and said they were going to sit till midnight, and invited me to go and dine with him at his lodgings, which I did. At 1/2 past 6. I returned to the house— At 1/2 past 5. after a Texas speech from Tibbats, they took a recess till 7. The Speaker then took the chair, and the house adjourned by yeas and nays 22 to 14.

Mr Lewis Johnson called this morning to enquire concerning the papers which he had left with me sustaining his claim as Administrator of Williams Otis, for the further allowance of interest upon the sum admitted to be due to him and which has been paid— He had requested me to examine these papers and if I approved them to write to Mr M’Culloch the Comptroller, or see him again to urge the Justice of the claim. I have waded through the papers which are voluminous, and begun writing to the Comptroller but have not yet finished my remarks on the case. But I read to Mr Johnson, a Letter that I had received a month since from Norton Quincy Thaxter, asking the return of a power of Attorney from Ximenes and Cogley to him which he had sent by me to Mr Johnson last Summer— Mr Johnson sent it to me this Evening to be forwarded to Mr Thaxter— The multitude of these petty details of private business requiring a continuous memory of incidents occurring at distant intervals of time is oppressive beyond all endurance— I am sinking irrecoverably under it.— I found the house in Session, discussing a motion made by Weller to repeal the order to take the Tariff Bill out of the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union at one O’Clock this day, and to protract the debate upon it till one O’Clock next Friday—but all the chicanery of order uses used to defeat this proposal, which failed by a vote of 92 to 77. not two thirds, Barnard appealed from the decision of the Speaker, that it required a majority of two thirds to rescind the resolution to take the bill out of Committee this day; but the Speaker’s decision was sustained— The skirmishing continued till near half past 12. and Burt of South Carolina had but the fragment of an hour for his solemn stupefactions— At one, the voting on the amendments commenced and continued three long hours, most of the amendments offered being rejected, but some of them adopted— At last the Committee rose and reported the Bill, and M’Kay chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means took the floor.— Barnard said he wanted to prove that this was not a revenue Bill, and would not yield the amount of revenue indispensable for the Government and there was much negotiation against a previous question before Saturday afternoon but no pledge obtained— In the midst of the parley an adjournment was moved and carried— Mr Clay was in the house again— I gave him a copy of Charles’s pamphlet on Texas and the Massachusetts Resolutions.

A new subject of political excitement is opening upon this country, the extent and duration of which it is impossible for me to foresee, but which must have great influence for good or evil (God grant it may be for good) upon the future history and fortunes of this Union— It is a deadly feud between the Native american poor population, and the Roman Catholic Irish multitudes gathered in the city of Philadelphia— The animosities between these two classes of people have been fermenting in all our atlantic cities for several years, and have been much aggravated by the pernicious factious influence of these Irish Catholics over the elections in all the populous cities.— The reaction of the native American population effected a total revolution in the recent election of the City Government of New-York— They have now broken out in furious riots at Philadelphia, where from the first of this week a succession of bitterly exasperated mobs, have destroyed multitudes of human lives—dwelling houses, schools and churches, unrestrained by the Government of the City or of the State.— At the house this morning immediately after the reading of the Journal Emery D. Potter of Toledo—5th. congressional District of Ohio announced the decease on the 30th. of last Month of Henry R. Brinkerhoff of Plymouth, 21st. district of that State— He had been sick at home from the commencement of the Session and never taken his seat.— Mr Potter is himself a young man not much accustomed to public speaking— He gave as usual a short biographical eulogy upon the deceased who was one of the self-made men who compose the great majority of the rulers of this country— He was 56 years old—born in Adams County Pennsylvania, of humble parents, the same year that I was graduated at Cambridge—emigrated in early boyhood with his father’s family to the wilderness of Cayuga County, New-York— Served as a Militia Officer in the last War with England—twice elected a member of the New-York Legislature Removed to Huron County Ohio in 1837. and in 1843 was elected to this 28th Congress from a District, Mr Potter said opposed to him in politics—owing no doubt to an opposite vote divided between two whigh candidates— A very common result where a mere plurality carries the election— Mr Potter moved the usual honorary neurological resolutions which were adopted without further remark, including the adjournment of the house. General Root came and brought to my seat a Letter containing a statement of the application of his neighbours for interposition with the Mexican President Santa-Anna to obtain the liberation of Cyrus K. Gleason— I walked home under a burning summer sun, and stop’d on my way at the Franklin Insurance Company. Received a dividend of 10 per Cent 633:50. which I deposited in the Patriotic Bank 254.87. as Executor of T. B. Johnson for the balance received from my Son, and 378.63. on my own account.

Among my troubles is that constantly recurring of distributing public documents, speeches and pamphlets, chiefly political. I received yesterday a number of pamphlet copies of my Son’s 9 Essays, first published in the Boston Courier on Texas and the Massachusetts Resolutions; and distributed a few of them, and also some other papers, which have been sent to me for that purpose— I received a check from the Speaker on the Bank of the Metropolis for 800 dollars and purchased of Charles J. Nourse 1000 dollars of Washington City Corporation 6 per Cent Stock at one per cent advance— This is a re-investment of the annual payment of 300 dollars received on theof April fromMorsell, and of the dividend received yesterday from the Franklin Insurance company— At the house Shepherd Cary a Democrat from Maine, and William L. Goggin a whig from Virginia successor to the late Thomas W. Gilmer took their seats— A Letter of resignation was read from Dixon H. Lewis of Alabama, whose twenty score of flesh have been transferred from slumber in the house to sleep in the Senate— He takes there the place of William R. King, a gentle Slavemonger, called by Jackson, Miss Nancy, and now appointed Minister to France, for a quarrel and threatened duel with H. Clay in 1841— The doom of the Tariff bill had been fixed for this day.— When the Bill was on Wednesday reported from the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to the house, the league of Slavery and besotted democracy, which rules the house and the land, dared not spring the previous question upon the debate. They wanted an hour speech from M’Kay, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means to wash down the pill, and Barnard, a member of the minority of that Committee claimed an hour to discuss the bill, as a measure of revenue— There was some dirty chicanery to deprive Barnard of the floor, but M’Kay in order to reserve for himself the last word, yielded the floor to Barnard, who in a speech full to the point demonstrated the utter absurdity of the bill as a measure of revenue— M’Kay replied feebly, and in a tone of voice so low that the house could not hear him—but he killed his hour— Cullom moved the previous question— Cave Johnson moved a call of the house, 203 members answered— Elmer moved to lay the bill and amendments on the table— Carried 105 to 99. Irvin moved to reconsider Lost 99 to 103— Motions to adjourn and postpone, lost before taking the question of reconsideration— Stewart said as there had been a death he moved to adjourn, and the house adjourned. Evening visits from Messrs. Connell and Lee—and at the invitation of Mr Winthrop I attended at his lodgings an evening party of all the whigs in Congress, at his lodgings. Mr. Clay was there.

I called this morning at the bank of the Metropolis and deposited there the check for 800 dollars received yesterday from the Speaker, and then drew a check for 1010. payable to the order of C. J. Nourse, for the certificate of Washington city corporation 6. per cent, which he sent me in the course of the day.— I have taken this course to retain written notices of the whole transaction— At the house Mr John Connell, entertain a hope that this day would be allowed to private business which for several weeks has been entirely excluded. But not a movement was made to take it up. This was the first of three days, assigned for the consideration of business concerning the District of Columbia— They had already been substituted for the first three days of the month, the original assignment, and Duncan had moved a reconsideration, with a view to take up his bill for holding up the Presidential election on the same day throughout the Union. The question of reconsideration was taken by yeas and nays, on a motion of Campbell chairman of the Committee on the District to lay it on the table. Carried 83 to 78.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Joseph R. Ingersoll in the Chair. Campbell, who is at death’s door in a consumption moved to take up the bill to extend the Charters of the District Banks— Cave Johnson first objected to this and proposed to take up the Senate’s bill to recharter the banks—but that has not yet passed the Senate. Cave Johnson still insisted upon taking up some other bill— After no small chicanery, to decide whether the bill was or was not taken up Cave Johnson prevailed to take the question by tellers and it was decided not to take it up 77 to 80. The bill taken up, was that providing for the insane asylum in the District of Columbia; whereupon an excursive debate sprung up and continued nearly three hours, and which terminated by changing from a bill to provide for an asylum to a mere appropriation to pay the board of the insane of the district now at Baltimore. The bill was then laid aside, and afterwards reported to the house and a bill in substance to abolish imprisonment for debt in the District of Columbia, was next taken up and started another debate which continued till past 4. and then the Committee rose and the house adjourned— At the request of Mr Morgan of New-York, I sat for Mr Anthony who took a Daguerrotype likeness of me. The Association of American Geologists and Naturalists have been several days in session here Commander Wilkes gave them a party this Evening to which he invited me, and which I attended— The meeting was numerous, but very few of them were known to me.— The paintings, engravings and maps of the exploring expedition were exhibited to view.— My family went to a concert by the famous violinist Vieux Tems

It had been announced for several successive weeks that Mr Tinsley the Chaplain of the house would preach a funeral discourse on the members of Congress recently deceased, and chiefly with reference to Heman Allen Moore. A succession of Strangers however occupied the Speakers chair on Sunday mornings—when it was Mr Tinsley’s turn, until this day when he gave the promised discourse to a very thin auditory. My wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa went with me. Mr Tinsleys text was from Amos 4.12—“prepare to meet thy God.” an awful admonition— The whole chapter is a terrible denunciation of divine judgments against the kingdom of Israel, for disregarding his chastisements and not returning to him— There was very little application of the discourse to Mr Moore or of any other of the recent sufferers except Thomas W. Gilmer whose virtues were again commemorated, and whose hapless fate was again deplored. Every dispensation of heaven, gracious or afflictive should operate as exhortation to wise and righteous action, but human ignorance and error make no account of them or give them a wrong direction— I dare not attribute the sudden and violent death of one man to a special retributive Providence any more than the natural and easy death of another.— Our heavenly father causeth his Sun to rise and his rain to fall alike upon the Evil and the Good, nor is perhaps sudden and instantaneous death more a token of divine wrath than the lingering tortures of dissolution by slow disease— Before dinner we had a visit from Mr Henry Clay, to take leave— In good health— He goes to-morrow for his home at Ashland in Kentucky.— His prospects of election to the Presidency are at this time brighter than they have ever been before, and I sincerely believe his success desirable for the best interests of the Country. There was again no service this afternoon at St John’s Church— I attended at the second Presbyterian, and heard Mr Knox from Matthew 25.21. [“]His lord said unto him, Well done, thou good and faithful servant; thou has been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.” Mr Knox is eloquent, fluent, rich in the copia verborum, and in his zeal evidently sincere— After the sermon, he gave an interesting account of his recent attendance at the dedication of a new presbyterian church at some village in Maryland, with symptoms of a revival— I made out this evening partly to answer two Letters from W. H. Seward of Auburn—New-York— Feebly.

Mr John Cranch had requested me to sit to him for my portrait, for his father, judge William Cranch, my cousin— At 9 this morning I sat to him in a small hut or shanty, at the foot of the capital hill and northern corner of the Pennsylvania avenue. An hour and a half exhausted his patience and mine, and I promised him another hour to-morrow morning— At the house this was the alternate Monday assigned by the rules of the house for the reception of Petitions, but since the 26th. of February, every petition and resolution day has been diverted to other business— Petitions may be entered at the Clerk’s table— Resolutions can be introduced by any member of the majority, but by no other— There were two special orders for this day—one the joint Resolution from the Senate to adjourn on the 27th. of May next—and the other, the district business, for the consideration of which this was the second of the three days— Cave Johnson called up immediately the Resolution for adjournment and moved the previous question—he was intent upon forcing the question upon the day—the 27th. bu the majority had determined against him that the adjournment should be fixed for the 17th. of June—propositions were made for substituting the 17th. and the 18th. of June; and Charles J. Ingersoll was urgent for striking out the day and leaving it in blank, alledging that the Committee of Foreign affairs had Treaties under their consideration— Cave Johnson still insisted upon his previous question till Parmenter observed that the 27th of May next would defer the adjournment till the next year Cave then moved to strike out the word next and insert current—cavil against this followed, and Cave retreated back again upon his call for the previous question— Charles J. Ingersoll then moved to lay the Resolution on the table—lost 22 to 178.— The motion for the previous question was also lost 56 to 112— The 17th. of June was substituted for the 27th of May next 114 to 88. and then the Senate Resolution was concurred in, without division— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Joseph R. Ingersoll in the chair— Bill for abolishing imprisonment for debt, in the District of Columbia; and a long combustious debate, a lack of quorum a call of the house, and the bill was laid aside to be reported— The City Charter Bill was taken up for a short time, and the District banks bill came in from the Senate, and raised a snarl in which the committee rose and the house adjourned— Call by the Revd. Obadiah B. Brown.

I received yesterday morning, in the house a note from the Revd. Obadiah B. Brown informing me that he was now ready to settle his debt, and would call on me for that purpose whenever it would suit my convenience— I answered that I would see him at my house at 7. O’Clock last evening; at which time he came and paid me 1070 dollars for his note of 1000. and 70 dollars for interest from 11. March 1843. This morning I deposited the bills at the Bank of the Metropolis and immediately after, purchased of Corcoran and Riggs, brokers a certificate for 1000 dollars of Washington City Corporation 6 per cents for 3/4 of one per cent advance— They sent me the certificate in the course of the day. From half past 9 O’Clock I sat to Mr John Cranch and Mr Bingham who occupy jointly the painting room for my portrait— At the house I found the clerk reading the journal of yesterday— Dawson introduced a Resolution of the Legislature of Louisiana relating to a survey of parts of the red river. Campbell moved to cease debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Washington City charter Bill at 1/2 past 12 O’Clock this day, carried without opposition— There was then a sharp struggle by Campbell to get the District Bank Bill from the Senate into Committee of the whole in which he finally succeeded, but could not get it taken up there. Cave Johnson, Weller, and Burke, trip’d him up in his oft repeated motions to take it up. Burke once moved to lay it on the table—lost by yeas and nays 70 to 94. but in Committee of the whole, where the yeas and nays cannot be taken, three successive motions to take it up were lost taken by tellers, with a quorum present, a majority of them voting to take up the bill, and a portion of the minority purposely not passing through the tellers; and thereby balking a quorum vote— A call of the house was moved, but refused— Campbell kept his temper, and carried sundry other district bills, first through the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Joseph R. Ingersoll in the Chair, and then through the Committee of the whole Samuel F. Vinton in the Chair; the two Committees successively rose, and about half past 4. the house adjourned, without acting upon any of the reported bills— The three days devoted to the consideration of District business have passed away, and the only bill of much importance to the District or the Country has been excluded from consideration by the party tactics of Cave Johnson, Weller and Burke— The Senate this day by a vote of 24 to 16. on the motion of R. J. Walker of Mississippi, laid on the table the joint Resolution to adjourn on the 17th of June— 12 members absent are not voting—a very bad omen— I took a short walk after dinner. Evening visit from Mr Thom. I answered two Letters from E. D. Marchant.

I called at the Office of Corcoran and Riggs, and paid for the certificate of Washington City Corporation 6. per cents received from them yesterday by a check on the Bank of the Metropolis for 1007.50.— The names in the margin, are those including my own of the select Committee, to whom on the 19th. of Feby last was referred the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury, on the Resolution of the House of the 3d. of January concerning the present condition of the Smithsonian fund— I met them at 10 this morning in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures; all present except Houston and Chappell who were duly notified— We had barely time to read the Will of Smithson—the act of Congress accepting the bequest and the report of the Secretary of the Treasury referred to the Committee; and adjourned to meet to-morrow at 10. O’Clock— In the house, Dellet of Alabama, by leave, presented Resolutions of a meeting at Mobile for the re-annexation of Texas, which without reading were laid on the table— M’Kay made an abortive attempt to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the appropriation bills, the Committees were called for Reports, many of which were presented, and among them two from the Post office Committee; the majority report announcing a bill, not yet ready.— And Charles J. Ingersoll from the Committee of foreign affairs reported a Resolution requesting the President to rescind as soon as may be done without giving just cause of complaint the reciprocity Treaties with the Hanse towns, Denmark and Sweden, and to modify that with Great Britain— Saunders chairman of the select Committee on the fight between White and Rathbun moved to reprint 2000 extra copies of the report and testimony, which after some wrangling was lost by yeas and nays 91. to 79.—not two thirds— Campbell moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the District Banks bill, interrupted by a resolution, moved by Weller to give 150 dollars to John L. Wirt for the expenses of his wound received in the fray between White and Rathbun, which was instantly carried without a negative vote— Campbell’s motion was lost by yeas and nays 59 to 112. Duncan’s bill for holding the election of Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States, on the same day throughout the Union, was taken up and driven through, rejecting an amendment moved by Elmer to postpone the operation of the act till after the election immediately approaching, and after two hours spent on a call of the house till twelve members were brought in, in custody of the Serjeant at arms, and then all further procedings were superseded.

Mr Gifford is a manufacturer of Shoes and boots at Braintree, Massachusetts— He came last evening with an introductory and commendatory Letter from Revd. Dr R. S. Storrs— I was not then at home. He called again this morning, and told me he had come here to apply to the bureau of supplies for the navy Department to obtain a contract to furnish several thousand pair of shoes for the navy. But he found it was too late— Others had preoccupied the ground, and as the contract must be given to the lowest bidder at whatever price he should offer to deliver the shoes they would offer to deliver them at two cents a pair lower— He should be obliged to take a subcontract as he had been the last year upon which the original contractors had realized enormous profits, and he little or nothing. They had contracted to deliver the shoes at 1 dollar and 10 cents a pair, for which he had been obliged to take 87 1/2 cents— They were to furnish them this year at 90 cents a pair, and the quality of the shoes must be more than proportionally debased— I met again the Committee on the Smithsonian bequest—the same members present as yesterday. The Report of the Secretary of the Treasury evades all explanation of the manner how the fund was almost entirely invested in bonds of the State of Arkansas, upon which no interest has been paid except in other bonds of the same State, and upon which for more than two years no interest has been paid at-all— How to make the fund now available for any appropriation by Congress to the purposes of the testator, was the question first discussed, and upon which the Committee came to no result.— Then I read the Bill reported by the select Committee on the 12th. of April 1842, and after some conversation the Committee adjourned to next Monday 10. O’Clock. for the Chairman consulting with judge French to prepare some specific measure to be discussed for report to the house— In the house I moved a suspension of the rules to present a Memorial from the American statistical association, on the errors in the printed 6th census—lost 97 to 49. I called on the Speaker to vote, as his vote if in the affirmative would have carried the two thirds— He refused to vote, and said if he did vote it would be in the negative— After some wrangling debate, the report on the White and Rathbun fisticuffs and the whole subject was laid on the table— The Eastern harbour bill was crammed through and finally carried by yeas and nays 96 to 80.— Holmes made two attempts to adjourn over to Monday. Both failures by yeas and nays. The ostensible reason was to ventilate and summer dress the hall— The real one to attend the races—

My wife was very unwell all day yesterday and had a very disturbed night— The last evening was of the calm summer sultry heat, the most insupportable to me of this climate, and disabled me totally for writing and for all action mental or bodily— Mr Hawley paid us an evening visit, convalescent from a fit of severe indisposition. He conversed rationally and piously upon his own condition, approaching the last stage of life, and made many remarks more applicable to me than to himself. I went this morning to the house, with a hope that they would devote this day to the consideration of private claims which for several weeks have been totally neglected.— I entered at the clerk’s table the Memorial from the American statistical Association, with direction to refer it to the select Committee on Statistics. The chairman of that Committee Zadok Pratt promised me, that they should report upon it to the house— But the Slave Oligarchy will yet prevail to suppress this document. In the house Saunders attempted to bring up the quarrel again, on the pretence of a privileged question, alledging that White had yesterday cast reflections upon his report, which he considered as reflections upon him, and he demanded an explanation— White said nothing, and the Speaker told Saunders that this was not a privileged question— The only good thing done by the house was at the motion of David L. Seymour, to transfer from the Committee of the whole house to the Committee of the whole house on the state of the Union, the house bill N. 7. extending the widows revolutionary pensions. Dean insisted upon going into committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Navy retrenchment Bill, but Vance called loudly for the orders of the day, on private claims and I conjured the house to give one day to mercy—in vain. Deans motion was almost unanimously rejected— The house went into Committee of the whole on private Bills— The Speaker called John White to the Chair; but he said he had an engagement elsewhere. The Speaker then gave the chair to Cave Johnson— A bill to allow a compensation to Seth Sweetser was laid aside—then came a bill to compensate Captain Allen of the ship Cadmus, for bringing General La Fayette from France in 1824 sprung a debate, which soon became sharp pointed— David L. Seymour to report against the passage of the bill.— Vote 62 to 45. no quorum— After a vain and heartless struggle the Committee rose and reported no quorum— At one O’Clock the house adjourned over to Monday at 11. I went to the chamber of the Committee of manufacturers and wrote till 4— Then home.

Mr Persico’s statues of Columbus and the Indian girl were yesterday taken from their boxes and hoisted upon the pedestal at the left summit of the flight of steps to the eastern central entrance to the Rotundo of the Capitol— The workman had been two days in raising the two statues, and as I left the Capitol yesterday to come home I saw them fully exposed— Soon after dinner Persico came to my house, almost convulsed with agitation to tell me that the statues were up, and was quite mortified when I told him I had seen them.— He was anxious to have been the first to announce to me the memorable event and he was going to announce it to President Tyler, and the Secretary of State Calhoun. He wanted also to shew me the statues, and hear what I should think of them, and I agreed to meet him there Monday morning— Aaron Lenox is an old ex-marine twice wounded in the last War with England: a petitioner for a pension, but destitute of sufficient evidence to sustain his claim.— Mrs Telfair came again— I told her I had yesterday supplicated the house to consider the private claims, and had chiefly hers in view— But they could not keep a quorum, and adjourned over to Monday— I despaired of all private claims before the house for this Session.— I took the papers relating to the claim of interest on the public debt due to the Administrator of William Otis, with my remarks upon them, to the first Comptroller of the Treasury M’Culloh and left them with him. He was engaged with another person— I told him the substance of my remarks— He said he would re-examine the case, and call and see me at my house before making his final decision.— I called at the Department of State, and spoke with the Secretary John C. Calhoun 1. On the application for Documents from the Government of New Brunswick, requested by Letter from John G Palfrey, Secretary of State to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 2. On the Resolution of H.R.U.S. calling on the President for copies of the Instructions to the African Squadron, and of the British Instructions to their Squadron, if they have been communicated 3. Upon the errors in the printed Census of 1840.— He called Mr Derrick to answer me on the first and second points; and answered like a true slave-monger on the third. He writhed like a trodden rattlesnake, on the exposure of his false report to the house, that no material errors have been discovered in the printed census of 1840—and finally said that where there were so many errors they balanced one another, and led to the same conclusion as if they were all correct— Calls, by Lewis Johnson Commodore Morris and Mr Thom.— After dinner I went with Isaac Hull—and Mary to see the Buffalo hunt at the race course— A wretched exhibition.

An advertisement in the National Intelligencer of yesterday announced that the Revd. Mr Anderson, Minister of a Baptist church in Salem Massachusetts, would preach in the hall of the house of Representatives this morning— I went there to hear him, but the hall was not yet in order, and no public worship could be held there.— I returned immediately, and at the second Presbyterian Church heard Mr Knox, preach from Hosea 6.4. “O Ephraim, what shall I do unto thee? O Judah, what shall I do unto thee? for your goodness is as a morning cloud and as the early dew, it goeth away.” Mr Knox remarked upon the extraordinary stirring vivacity of the style of the scriptural prophets—in no instance more remarkable than in this text— Ephraim and Judah, are the two kingdoms— The book of Hosea extends over a period of 60 years from 784 to 724. before Christ, and is cotemporaneous with that of Isaiah.— Throughout the Book;—the sins of the two Peoples in punishment for which the judgments of God are denounced consist first of idolatry, figured under the name of adultery, and whoredom an imagery carried through the whole of the old testament, from the departure out of Egypt to the restoration of Jerusalem and the building of the second temple— The divine mission of Hosea is of a character so revolting that it requires Faith almost superhuman to be reconciled to— The prophet is commanded by the word of the Lord to commit a disgusting crime The narrative cannot be read with decency; and yet the book is a code of the purest morality, and the tenderest affections. What can be more compassionate than these apostrophes to Ephraim and Judah? What more thrilling than the likening of their goodness to the morning cloud and the early dew— Mr Knox gave notice that the Revd. Mr. Ewing of Philadelphia, would preach at 4 this afternoon— I believe, a son of my old friend Samuel Ewing, many years gone to the world of Spirits— I went to hear this young man, whose text was from Job 12.7. “But ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee; and the fowls of the air, and they shall tell thee” Mr Ewing’s manner is over emphatic, and with critical hearers incurs the charge of affectation—so said Mr Hazard whom I met in coming out of church—but his zeal is glowing and his heart sincere— We had evening visits from General Clinch—Mrs Dawson, and Mr and Mrs Toombs of Georgia— My wife is recovering— Louisa quite unwell.

I had prepared a draught of a Bill, making an appropriation of 700,000 dollars from the treasury; to assume the annual interest on the Smithson fund, invested now in stocks of several States, and upon interest the payment of which is suspended; which draught I proposed to submit to the consideration of the Committee on the Smithsonian bequest at their meeting this morning. But only one member of the Committee Jacob S. Yost attended.— I read my draught of a bill to him; and we agreed to meet again next Wednesday morning at 1/2 past 9.— Persico was not at the entrance of the Capitol, where I had agreed to meet me; but I received a note from him this evening, stung by a censorial article in the Baltimore Sun, upon the nakedness of his Indian girl— In the house there was no attempt made to call for resolutions. But Campbell offered Resolutions from a portion of his constituents for the re-annexation of Texas, which were laid on the table and ordered to be printed.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, George C. Dromgoole in the Chair— Several bills were proposed to be taken up by several members— Dean was very urgent to take up his navy retrenchment bill— Campbell to take up the District Banks bill; and John W. Davis to take up the bill to reduce and graduate the price of the public lands.— But Dromgoole playing into the hands of M’Kay, put first the question upon his motion to tae up the Post-Office appropriation Bill and it was carried— Garret Davis moved to reduce the pay of the special agents of the Postmaster general, and told a very shameful story about Wickliffe’s employing one of these agents to electioneer against him and for his competitor a nephew of Wickliff— Davis said he had charged this upon Wickliff to his face, and twice told him it was a cowardly action to which Wickliff’s only reply was, that is a matter of opinion Mr Davis. Rathbun moved to strike out the appropriation for the special agents to which Schenk moved an addition to leave an appropriation of 5000 dollars to defray the expence of declaring frauds this amendment was carried and reported to the house, and the Navy Appropriation bill, and this after some skirmishing brought on a premeditated debate upon Texas— Holmes of South-Carolina broached it in a set and laboured speech others will follow. Parmenter, Hamlin Cave Johnson; Hale and Slidell moved restrictive amendments; and Dickinson moved the establishment of a naval depot at Memphis Tennessee Committee rose after 4. Adjourned.

I gave a siting of an hour, this morning to Mr John Cranch, and Mr Bingham: neither of whom is likely to make out either a strong likeness or a fine picture— At the house L. Q. C. Elmer chairman of the Committee of Elections, presented a report from the majority of that Committee on the petition of John M Botts, contesting the election of John W. Jones, the Speaker of the house who put Weller into the chair while this matter was before the house. The report was laid on the table and ordered to be printed— The documents were ordered to be postponed till to-morrow on the motion for printing them. Robert C. Schenk announced a minority report to be presented hereafter.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dromgoole in the Chair— Duncan moved to take up the bill for the occupation of the Oregon, by extending over it the jurisdiction of the territory of Ioway, and he called for Tellers, who returned the vote 30 to 95— As I passed through the tellers in the negative, to Duncan, “not quite yet, Doctor”— And I might have said not at all.— The naval appropriation bill was taken up. Parmenter had moved an amendment to specify some parts of the appropriation, and Cave Johnson moved to strike out all appropriations for the Navy-yard at Washington, and to establish a Navy yard at Memphis, Tennessee— Sample and Ashe made warm speeches in favour of this amendment, whereupon Cave Johnson withdrew it, and Washington of Hunt moved to limit the sum to be expended for the service of the Navy, excepting for the Navy-Yard to one half the whole amount before the first of January 1845— Hunt supported his amendment with A speech avowing his apprehension that the President will squander the appropriations to plunge the Country into a War, by his usurpation of the Constitutional power of Congress. Archibald Atkinson then broke out with an annexation speech; backed by one from Robert Dale Owen, the Scotch infidel from Lanark— Morse made a short speech on the other side— James E. Belser followed with a red hot Texan annexation speech; and was answered by Giddings with an intrepid exposure of the whole transaction of the Texan Treaty— He was frequently interrupted by several of the Slavers in a an overbearing and bullying tone and in every instance met and signally discomfited them— W. W. Payne swelled with venom like a toad and threatened a Resolution to maintain the dignity of the house, but Dromgoole pronounced it not in order, and M’Kay moved to take the bill out of Committee to-morrow at 3. O’Clock P.M. adjourned after 5 Evening visits from W. Cost Johnson and John Connell.

The Meeting of the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest was appointed for half past 9 O’Clock this morning, but with myself only three other members of the Committee were in attendance, Brengle, Potter and Yost— Not a Quorum. I read to them my draught of a bill for appropriating 700000 dollars from the Treasury for carrying into immediate effect the purposes of the Testator which they all approved; and they were also willing also to report again the bill which was reported in 1842. We adjourned to meet again next Saturday— I then gave a sitting of half an hour to Gibert who retouched my portrait which he had painted from the life He has also painted another portrait of me from the daguerrotype likeness taken by Anthony and Edwards— A hideous likeness— At the house, Belser of Alabama and Cobb of Georgia presented Resolutions of meetings in those States in favour of the immediate annexation of Texas. Cave Johnson called up his motion to reconsider the order to print the documents reported by the Committee of Elections on the contest between Botts and Jones. The vote to reconsider passed, without opposition, and then the consideration of the motion to print was postponed till next Saturday. Then Hamilton Fish of New-York city offered a resolution for the appointment of a select Committee of five to enquire and report to the house whether the franking privilege of any member of the house has been violated by any deputy Postmaster or officer of the Post Office Department under any regulation or Instruction of the Department.— Fish was at first screwed out of his motion upon the point of order, by the Speaker; but he afterwards renewed and carried it, by obtaining a suspension of the rules. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dromgoole in the chair The naval appropriation bill was taken up and debated till 3. O’Clock, and then commenced the voting upon the multitude of proposed amendments, which continued till past 4. when the Committee rose— Several messages from the President were presented by the Speaker—among which, one in answer to the call of 3 January last for copies of the instructions to the squadrons on the coast of Africa— The copies are refused.— Adjourned, and I walked home— Mr Wines and Mr Madison Cutts were here this evening.

I began the draught of a Report to accompany the Bill which I propose to report from the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest, but made little progress in it— I sat an hour to Mr Cranch, and Mr Bingham for my portrait— At the house Howell Cobb of Georgia made a desperate and repeated struggle to introduce and have printed a string of Resolutions adopted at a small village popular meeting in Georgia. White objected not to the reception or laying on the table of the Resolutions, but to their being printed. Cobb persisted and moved a suspension of the rules— White moved a call of the house—lost 42 to 121. only 163 in all, 40 members absent or not voting— Cobb’s motion to suspend the rules was lost 75 to 99.— Duncan L. Clinch moved to suspend the rules to introduce counter-Resolutions; but the motion was not in order— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dromgoole in the chair— Naval Appropriation bill first taken up numerous amendments proposed, and among them one by M’Kay Chairman of the Committee of ways and means of an additional appropriation of 600–700000 dollars, to supply the deficiencies of the last years appropriation, upon a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy that the money has been expended— I asked whether this amendment could be debated— The chairman said no—whereupon I objected to the reception of it as not in order—the rule of the house prescribing that all appropriations shall be first discussed in Committee of the whole. The Chairman declared the amendment in order— I appealed from the decision— The Committee sustained the Chairman—but M’Kay withdrew his amendment, and said he would bring it in, by a separate bill— The Post-Office appropriation Bill was afterwards taken up, and the amendment to abolish the special agents of the Post Office Department was rejected 73 to 81. Then the fortification bill from the Senate, and the Louisiana Land claim, followed till half past 4. and the house adjourned— Mrs Smith came again to pass some time with us.— Other visitors came and passed the whole or part of the evening with us— Mr Perry is a professor of Mathematics in the Navy, recently returned from a three years Cruise in the Chinese and India seas in the Constellation frigate— I walked from the house home

Mr Connell called on me this morning to urge the devotion of this day in the house of Representatives, to private business—his claim in behalf of the heirs of Robert Fulton standing the second bill on the private Calendar.— There is not the remotest chance of the passage of this bill.— I gave a sitting of an hour to Mr Cranch and Mr Bingham, for my Portrait— I found the house in Session. Alcée La Branche was attempting to introduce Resolutions of a meeting at New-Orleans in favour of the re-annexation of Texas to the United States; and had moved to refer them to a select Committee of five— After no small trickery to carry this point Parmenter moved to lay the Resolutions on the table.— C J. Ingersoll moved a call of the house—rejected 59 to 98. And the Resolutions were laid on the table 103 to 78.— Joseph Vance, an Ohio whig moved that when the house should adjourn to Wednesday next. The motive was to give time to the members of the democracy to attend the democratic Conventions to be held at Baltimore next Monday to nominate candidates for election as President and Vice-President of the United States for four years from the 4th. of March 1845. Vance’s motion was that when the house should adjourn to-morrow, it should be to Wednesday; and he said he made it at their request— But they called the yeas and nays and rejected the motion 42 to 137. Duncan moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; to take up the bill to extend the jurisdiction of the United States over the territory of Oregon—lost 85 to 89. Reports from Committees were called for and made in the multitudes. Joseph R. Ingersoll obtained a suspension of the rules and introduced a bill to amend the Pension Laws. Referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and David L. Seymour moved immediately to go into that Committee to take up the widows pension bill, which was done. The bill was debated till past four and numerous amendments proposed and discussed— Vance still remonstrating that this was private bill day.— At last Garret Davis moved an additional section, to extend the pension system to the warriors against the Indians until Wayne’s Treaty of Greenville, which enlarged the debate, till the Committee rose and the house adjourned— As evening visitors we has our neighbours Mrs Young and her daughter, Mr and Mrs Grinnell, Mr Winthrop and Mr Thom.

The meeting of the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest was fixed for this morning at half past 9. but the only members who attended except myself were Brengle and French— I read my draught of a preliminary bill to appropriate a sum sufficient to make the fund immediately available for application to the purposes of the testator, to Mr French who without hesitation approved it— I have therefore the consent of a majority of the Committee to report it, but I was not ready with my report— It was agreed therefore that when my report is ready, I shall call a meeting of the Committee for their final action upon the reference At the house, the journal of yesterday was only read in part— At the motion of John Slidell of New-Orleans the reading was superseded without objection, before it was half concluded— A bad practice; because it precludes the correction of errors which are frequent and often important— Cave Johnson’s motion to reconsider the order for printing the documents reported by the Committee of Elections in the context between John W. Jones, and John M. Botts, was postponed from Monday to Wednesday next— At Slidell’s motion the order was made that all debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the bill in relation to the Louisiana Land claims shall cease on Thursday next at 4 O’Clock P.M. Zadok Pratt, chairman of the Committee on the Public buildings and grounds reported sundry resolutions of which was one directing the Commissioner of Public buildings to remove the shed over the statue of Washington in the square East of the Capitol, and sell it, and with the proceeds of the sale to pay for a suitable railing round the Statue. Debate and a violent speech of John P Hale against the Statue. Winthrop defended the Sculptor and at his motion the Resolution was referred to a select Committee of five. Wentworth attempted to introduce a crazy or fraudulent memorial from Joe Smith the Mormon prophet which was not received 79 to 86— Committee of the whole on the private Calendar R. C. Winthrop in the Chair— 96 bills and resolutions were reported to the house, without objection, and one to which I objected too late. I appealed from the decision of the chairman, but on failure of a quorum withdrew my appeal— Sundry motions to adjourn over to Wednesday and to Tuesday next, all of which failed.— After dinner the Marine band played on the grounds at the President’s house, where I met sundry old acquaintance. Other visitors came in the Evening to my house.

A day of extreme summer heat. In the hall of the house of Representatives, Mr Tinsley preached from Luke 15.18— “I will arise and go to my father” he took no more of the parable for his text; but this was enough to let into his commentary the whole story of the prodigal son—an inexhaustible fountain of the tenderest affections of the human heart. Mr Tinsley threw himself on the indulgence of a very small auditory observing that he was much indisposed and had hoped to have obtained assistance to supply his place, but had been disappointed. He spoke without notes, with sufficient fluency, but with little effect— I never hear a discourse upon this parable without being reminded of that of Sterne.— The general analogy which makes the prodigal the impersonation of all mankind in their relation to their maker, appeals to the bosom and to the conscience of every individual— The essence of the Christian religion considers every man as a sinner, and repentance as the condition of salvation— The creed requires the belief that the atonement of Christ is the price of salvation, and that doctrine was enforced this afternoon at St. John’s church, by a Stranger who read the Evening service for Whitsunday, and preached from Ephesians 2.8 “For by grace are ye saved, through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: 9. Not of works, lest any man should boast.” The doctrine that man cannot save himself by good works is harsh and hard to believe, but the doctrine taught by the parable of the prodigal Son is that Salvation is secured by repentance and Faith. Good works are the necessary and indispensable sequel to sincere repentance—in ceasing to do evil we learn to do good—good works are the proofs of repentance, but they are parts of the relations of man with his fellow man; not with God— They can have no merit in his intercourse with God—nor give to man the right to boast. While the preacher this afternoon was discoursing on this theme a sudden heavy thunder gust and shower came up, and there was one flash and clap so instantaneous that it might well it well have discomposed the equanimity of his nerves but did not— He only took occasion from it to notice how the life or man was liable to be cut off in an instant Walter Hellen and Mr Thom were here this evening.

This was the day on which the two democratic conventions to nominate candidates for the offices of President and Vice President of the United States, for four years from the fourth of March next were held at Baltimore— And also a Convention to nominate a candidate for the office of Governor of Maryland— By the new invention of the Electro-magnetic telegraph of professor Morse, the proceedings of these bodies throughout the day were made known here at the Capitol, and announced as soon as received in manuscript bulletins suspended to the wall in the Rotundo. I gave an hour’s sitting to Mr Cranch and Mr Bingham, after calling at the National Intelligencer Office and leaving with Mr Gales a continued list of Petitions presented by me, since the 5th. of April— And with it, I left the Boston Courier of the 14th. containing the memorial relating to the statistics of the census, which I requested Mr Gales to republish, with a reference asterisk from the entry of the memorial on my list— The use made by John C. Calhoun in his correspondence with Mr Pakenham, of these enormous blunders in the census, and his prevarication, in denying in an official report that any errors had been discovered in the census, betray so total a disregard of all moral principle that it can be attributed only to the alternative of absence of honesty or of mental sanity— Tis the fanaticism of the Slave-monger. At the house, the business of the day dragged heavily along— About 70 members chiefly of the democratic majority were absent at Baltimore, yet enough remained to controul the action of the house, and dictate what should be done— Mr Grinnell offered a Resolution requesting the joint Committee on the Library to consider the expediency of publishing 3000 copies of certain surveys of the exploring expedition, and selling them to defray the cost of publication, which was adopted. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Reuben Chapman of Alabama in the Chair, and George S Houston of the same Alabama drove through too land bills, which were reported to the house— Weller moved to adjourn over to Wednesday, but on call of the yeas and nays withdrew the motion— I had insisted upon a call of the yeas and nays to ascertain the quorum in the house 110 and 19. Adjourned at 3.— I went into the Senate chamber and heard William C. Rives close a three hours tariff speech.— After dinner, Mr Carroll the clerk of the U.S Supreme Court came and introduced to me a Revd. Mr Smith of the State of Michigan who presented me a subscription book for the erection of a school house in the wilderness— Mr Carroll said there was much dissension at Baltimore.

The Summer heat prematurely coming upon me, as did the winter cold, from the day of my departure, last October (25) from my home at Quincy, disqualifies me, more and more from day to day for all useful action.— I gave an hour’s sitting again to Mr Cranch and Mr Bingham— It was to have been the last, but they requested one more. At the house, there was a Quorum of 135 members in attendance, under the dominion of Weller, unable to make a majority for his mischievous purposes, but sufficient to defeat any purpose of good by withholding votes necessary to make a Quorum— His course was—1. he moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up some pet measure of his own. His motion failed— Other motions were made to go into Committee which he defeated. Vance moved to take up the private bills, unobjectionable, reported to the house, last Saturday— Weller, said no—he would take up no private bill in the absence of his friend from Tennessee—Cave Johnson—the scourge of all claimants. At last David L. Seymour, carried a vote to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, with a view to take up the widows pension bill— John White was chairman of the Committee When the motion was made to take up the Bill, Weller called for a division— The votes were three to one for taking up the Bill, but Weller and his gang by not voting at-all prevented a quorum vote. Tellers were called— Four times over the count was repeated, and no quorum voted. The last count shewed 81 to 29. requiring only one vote more to make a quorum.— Weller at the issue of every count insisted that the Committee should rise and report no quorum to the house— He finally prevailed, and it being evident that no business could be done, the house between one and 2 adjourned— I had an hour of conversation with D. D. Barnard Joseph R. Ingersoll and other whigs, impatient to impeach Tyler for his manifold usurpations, and violations of the Constitution, which I dissuaded as impracticable, or a cracked gun barrel fit only to explode in the hand of him who would use it. The electro-magnetic telegraph, at the east-end of the Capitol was all day reporting every half hour the proceedings of the Conventions at Baltimore. The Tyler Convention adjourned without nominating a Vice-President. The Democratic National Convention adopted the two thirds rule and balloted 7 times between Van Buren and Cass without coming to a choice. After dinner I walked round the President’s square— We had evening visits from Mr Silsbee and his Son, and Mr Stone; all of Salem— Also from George Thom, Mary dined at her friend Mrs Turnbull’s.

It is impossible for me to describe the anxieties, under which my soul is oppressed, and which I am compelled to suppress, with reliance only upon superior power to relieve me from them— And with no hope of other relief than from the close of life, and the transition to another state of existence— The deepest of my afflictions is the degeneracy of my Country, from the principles which gave her existence—and the ruin irreparable of them all under the transcendant power of Slavery and the Slave representation.— This morning I gave another hour to Mr Cranch for my portrait. Bingham had already finished his. I had taken to them yesterday Stewart’s last Portrait of my father; of which Mr Cranch had once made a copy, but of which he wishes to make another— At the house there was a call of the yeas and nays on the passage of a bill to require the execution of bonds by Collectors of the Customs, before taking the oath of Office—to ascertain if there was a quorum present— The vote was 126 to 1. nays. The consideration of the Report of the Committee of Elections, on the contested election between the Speaker Jones, and John M Botts was postponed till next Friday— Several successive motions to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union were made and rejected, till one made by M’Kay with notice of his intention to call up the naval appropriation bill, succeeded— The house went into Committee— Weller in the chair, and took up not the naval appropriation, but the widows pension bill.— Sundry languid prosy speeches in support of Garret Daviss amendment to extend the pension Laws to the combatants against Indians till Waynes treaty of Greenville of 1795. and a further amendment to extend the system to the War of 1812. with Great-Britain— Andrew Stewart rose and said he proposed to make a speech about the Tariff— Objection was immediately made to his proceeding on the ground that any thing he could say upon the tariff would be irrelevant— The chairman after some hesitation so decided, from which decision Stewart appealed— The vote on the appeal was 54 to 4. Not within sight of a Quorum— The Committee rose, and before 2 the house adjourned— I walked home— The democratic National Convention at Baltimore this day unanimously nominated James K. Polk of Tennessee, their Candidate for the Office of President of the United States for 4 years from the 4th of March next and Silas Wright of New-York, as Vice President— B. F. Butler withdrew the name of Van Buren by his own authority. Wright declined the nomination. Evening call from W Cost Johnson

In preparing the Report to the house of the select Committee on the Smithson bequest I found it advisable to ascertain at the Treasury Department whether any further payment of interest upon any of the State bonds has been made into the Treasury since the Letter of the Secretary (John C. Spencer[)] of 19. Feby last referred to the Committee— I called at the Department, and Mr Young the chief Clerk and acting Secretary informed me that no additional payment has been made.— I then went to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions with two Letters of enquiry respecting pension claims of Sally Clark, and of the legal representatives of Phebe Thayer. I left the Letters, with the Commissioner, James L. Edwards who promised to give me the information in writing.— At the house, most of the democratic members who have been absent, attending the Democratic Convention at Baltimore had returned. Silas Wright having finally declined their nomination of him as Vice President, they nominated George M. Dallas of Pennsylvania for that office—then passed resolutions for the immediate occupation of Texas and of Oregon and then adjourned, with a solemn protest of one of the delegates from the State of Missouri against the whole proceedings, and a declaration that Missouri would not confirm them— In the house a joint Resolution for taking sundry inventories of public property, and a catalogue of the document library of the house, was introduced by Zadok Pratt, and after some discussion referred to the joint Committee on the library of Congress— I moved to add a consideration of the expediency of printing a 10th Volume of the U.S Laws— Pratt declined accepting my amendment—his resolution was adopted— And mine was received and passed in the form of a Resolution, requiring the Clerk of the house to have a tenth volume of the Laws published. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Weller in the chair. Campbell attempted to call up the District Bank Bill, by appealing to the sympathies of the members by stating that he wanted to go to Philadelphia to take medical advice—but in vain— The widow’s pension Bill was taken up, and after two or three more speeches for the warriors of the west, Garret Daviss motion to pension them and its rider were rejected and the bill was laid aside to be reported to the house— The Louisiana land title bill was then debated, till 4 O’Clock, when it had been ordered that the bill should be taken out of the Committee—sundry amendments were proposed, but as soon as a question arose upon which a division was called there was no quorum voting, the Committee rose, and the house adjourned

I finished the draught of a Report from the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest, but in the process of preparing it changed my purpose from the design of reporting two bills, to that of including the whole subject in one— At the house I presented by leave of the house a petition ofTarr and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, native americans, praying for an alteration of the naturalization laws to require of 21 years of naturalization, residence for the admission of foreigners to the political rights of native Americans— The petitioners not one of whom is personally known to me requested me in presenting it to the house to give my opinion upon its merits— This required of me a painful operation, for I do not approve the change of the Law petitioned for and know that an odious colouring will be given to the mere presentation of the petition— But I did not feel it becoming in me to refuse to present the petition, nor yet to shrink from the avowal of my opinion against it— I therefore presented the petition, stated the facts and said as the petitioners had chosen to call for my opinion, I felt myself obliged to say that I could not support its prayer— I moved its reference to the judiciary committee. J. W. Brown of Indiana and Hammett of Mississippi moved to lay it on the table which was carried by yeas and nays 128 to 26. Charles J. Ingersoll voted first no, and after the close of the call changed his vote. The Senate this morning concurred with the joint Resolution from the house to close the Session on the 17th. of this month— Willoughby Newton presented a report from the minority of the Committee of elections presented a report on the contested election between the Speaker and Botts—both the reports come to the same conclusion that Jones was duly elected. There was some argument that there was no question left for debate; but after some discussion it was finally concluded to postpone the consideration of the Resolution till next Thursday, and that Botts should if he desired it be heard at the bar in support of his claim— The motion to print the voluminous testimony in the case was laid on the table.— Vance made a motion to take up the bills on the private Calendar—but Cave Johnson moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and prevailed— The Louisiana Land claims—the Dead horses of Georgia, and the establishment of a Navy Yard at Memphis, Tennessee occupied the remainder of the day— Adjourned at half past 4.— Evening visits from Mr Connell, Miss Cutts, Miss Payne and Captain Riotous democratic mass meeting to confirm the nomination of Polk and Dallas.
